awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Modeling Spatiotemporal Control of EGFR-ERK Signaling in Gene-edited Cell Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, the investigators will develop a new experimental and computational platform to answer the longstanding biological question of how cellular receptors generate biochemical signals as they move among various subcellular compartments. By helping to quantitatively resolve certain apparently conflicting observations that have recently been made within a biological system previously thought to be well understood, this project will add fundamentally new understanding of basic mechanisms of cell signaling that may have implications across numerous receptor systems in cell biology. Moreover, due to the broadly important role that receptors, and the biochemical signals they generate, play in virtually every biological process, the new quantitative understanding gained will ultimately impact ongoing efforts to optimally engineer receptor-mediated signaling. This project also includes a broad and detailed set of integrated educational objectives that leverage the specific scientific objectives and activities of this project to reach students at different training stages and from diverse backgrounds. These education and outreach activities involve innovation upon existing programs at the partnering institutions as well as the creation of new outreach efforts that will target larger audiences, such as a summer academy of science for high school students and a collaboration with the Museum of Science and Industry in Tampa, FL to develop a live interaction program on cell signaling.
 
The biochemical signaling that results upon ligand binding to receptor tyrosine kinases is accompanied by receptor clustering and internalization, or endocytosis. While it has been understood for decades that endocytosis enables cells to degrade or recycle receptors, the question of how endocytosis ultimately impacts downstream signal propagation remains wide open. For example, even for the highly studied epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) the literature contains highly cited, yet conflicting reports that conclude that EGFR endocytosis either promotes or impedes downstream signaling through the extracellular regulated kinase (ERK) pathway. In this project, the investigators will explore the hypothesis that the intrinsic complexity of the spatiotemporal signaling regulatory mechanisms creates parameter spaces for both answers to be true depending on the cellular context. The complexity of the receptor trafficking and signaling system cannot be fully dissected, however, without integrating quantitative experimental measurements that faithfully reflect cell biology with spatiotemporal computational models. Accordingly, the overarching goal of this project is to combine novel live-cell imaging of gene-edited cell systems with mechanistic models that capture system complexity with unprecedented detail to resolve the kinds of conflicting reports previously mentioned, as well as more recent surprising observations that certain proteins conventionally thought to remain in complex during signal transduction may become physically separated through trafficking processes. Ultimately, the proposed integration of gene-edited cell systems, quantitative live-cell imaging and biochemical measurements, and a spatiotemporal computational model will lead to an entirely new quantitative platform to answer these kinds of questions for EGFR and other receptor signaling systems.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia

por.por_cntn:
The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) has been studied for decades because of its ubiquitously important roles in development, health, and disease. EGFR spans cell membranes, binds proteins outside the cell, and communicates (or signals) to cells to execute decisions to differentiate, migrate, survive, and proliferate. Because these processes integrate multiple time and length scales, there is a tremendous amount yet unknown about quantitative aspects of EGFR signaling and cell-fate determination. Indeed, while many qualitative aspects of the system have been described, much remains poorly understood in terms of how normal EGFR rate processes are regulated with spatiotemporal precision in health and perturbed outside the control of normal feedback regulation in disease. This lack of basic understanding hinders fundamental biological discovery and eventual applications toward improving health. In this project, we worked collaboratively with investigators at three other universities to develop unprecedented understanding of quantitative aspects of EGFR signaling.

A central accomplishment of this project was to develop an explanation for the paradoxical observation made by one of our project collaborators that, in some cells, EGFR becomes physically separated from the downstream pathway intermediate RAS (due to receptor internalization) while EGFR and RAS still cooperate to drive pathway flux. Conventional understanding required that EGFR and RAS be colocalized to cooperate in signaling, but we showed through a combined computational modeling and experimental effort that internalized (or endocytosed) EGFR activates a diffusible intermediate that regulates RAS back at the cell surface to propagate signaling. The most elaborate version of the models we developed captured the dynamic internalization of EGFR into small intracellular vesicles that move away from the membrane and regulate receptor degradation and recycling. Another version of the dynamic signaling model we developed explored the recent observation that some key proteins in the canonical signaling pathway can be expressed at surprisingly low levels and showed how this leads to noisy or stochastic pathway behavior and limited pathway flux (i.e., creates a signaling bottleneck). Thus, a conserved set of pathway proteins can operate in substantially different ways in different cell settings where key nodes are expressed at very different levels. Importantly, in developing the models described above, we trained our computational models against the best available experimental data generated by us and our collaborators. A particularly important set of data from our collaborator came from gene-edited cell lines where important pathway proteins were expressed at normal levels from the normal gene locations but as fusions with fluorescent proteins that enabled tracking by microscopy of protein abundances and subcellular localization over time.

In addition, we developed a new class of computational model that integrates mechanistic models with data-driven models to connect cellular ligand inputs to cell decisions. This new framework allows for the quantitative prediction of how the properties of the receptor-binding growth factors (e.g., their affinities, or the tightness of their binding to the receptors) impact the decisions that cells make. After developing the basic framework, we trained it on data that we generated to create a model capable of explaining cell decisions to either migrate or differentiate in response to ligands for EGFR that have very different binding affinities. Successful demonstration that this class of models can be created and used to predict the dependence of cell phenotypes on different signaling pathways for different EGFR ligands opens new possibilities for the field of cell biological modeling. For example, it enables the field to design novel proteins with specific properties to drive signaling through the EGFR in ways that are optimized for a prescribed cell outcome. It also enables calculations of how to combine or schedule cellular inputs for optimized or desired cell decisions.

Thus, funding from this NSF award was used by a collaborating team of investigators to develop new levels of understanding of a widely important receptor in biology. The implications of the completed work extend far beyond the study of EGFR and have the potential to impact fundamental discoveries and modeling applications across the field of receptor-mediated cell signaling.

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2024
Modified by: Matthew J Lazzara
